transcription.text: [ Music ]
Hi. Yeah, excellent.
So, yeah, I'm going to talk about vocal trees.
I've been making a few presentations about those already,
but they tended to be a bit too deep, technically speaking.
So, because this is DEFCON and we're trying to onboard more people,
this one is going to be a bit more high level, so hopefully enough to raise your interest in vocal trees.
So, yeah, why are we considering vocal trees?
It's basically a big change in the way Ethereum functions,
so why do we want to risk this?
Well, there are several reasons.
The first one is we want to be able to build blocks as self-contained execution units.
At the moment, Ethereum has a bit of a problem that when you want to join the network,
or if you haven't followed the network for a while,
you need to go through a process that's called a sync synchronization.
You cannot access the state directly.
It's like you cannot just download the state.
You cannot download the state, but it's a fairly convoluted process.
So, the idea is that if you include in the block everything that you need,
you can just download the block and execute it and see if you're interested.
Like, even before you execute the block, you can even know if it's going to be of interest to you or not,
and if it's of interest to you, you can execute it.
Otherwise, you don't even have to care.
So, it's something that is -- it's to build something that is in between a full client
and like a full node and a light client in the sense that you are still supposed to follow blocks,
but you don't have to hold the entire state.
And it's nice because it paves the way for other upgrades,
or it makes other upgrades a bit simpler.
For example, if you want to shuffle committees between shards in the future,
you don't want shards to charge the validators to keep following the chain at all times,
like several chains at all time.
So, it's something that's going to help them get up to speed a bit faster.
And, of course, there's the idea of state expiry, like the state of Ethereum is quite large,
so we want to be able to delete some of the state, but we don't want to delete and forget forever.
If your state has been deleted but you want to use it again, you need to provide a proof
to resurrect your state, and the idea is that vertical trees make your proofs smaller,
so it will be cheaper for you to resurrect the state.
So, because it's a fairly deeply technical topic, I have tried to make a simpler explanation with pirates.
So, imagine you have four pirates, and they bury a treasure somewhere,
and they plot the directions to get to the treasure on the map,
and then they want to go their separate ways.
So, if they adopt the method, like the metaphorical method that we currently use in these terms,
to store the Ethereum state, what they would do is they would split the map in four bits,
and then each of the pirates would get their own bits.
When they want to access the treasure, they need to put all the pieces of the map together.
The problem is inheritance.
If one of the pirates wants to retire, and for example, wants to sell you his bit of the map,
how do you know he's not selling you a fake map, a fake piece of the map?
He's a pirate, after all, so you should be careful.
Well, the problem was this method that was chosen.
To figure that out, you need at least the other two pirates to check that the pattern matches.
The proof size is quite involved.
It requires you to take the siblings, the sibling pieces.
Now, if we used the proofing technique that is suggested by vertical trees,
which is based on something called vector commitments, hence the name vertical,
what you do is you cut out something at the center, some little stub,
and you make this little stub as hard to reproduce as possible,
ideally cryptographically impossible to fake, and then everybody goes their separate ways.
When you want to buy your part of the map, all you have to do is make sure that your piece fits into that proof,
that little stub.
Of course, we don't use pieces of paper.
We use chromatography, stronger chromatography than this.
Now, this is your proof size.
How do you transpose this to vertical trees?
Well, the current ethereum state is stored in a tree where all the data of ethereum is at the bottom of the tree,
and then you group them, the parent is a commitment, the parent node is a commitment,
and then the parent of that parent is also a commitment all the way to the top,
and the root of the tree is ending up in the block.
So if you want to prove in a tree, for example, the purple square here,
if you use the current method, it's the same thing as with the pirates.
For each level, you have to pass the siblings.
And here, this is a very simple representation, but in ethereum, each parent node has 16 children,
and the consequence of this is that you need to pass 15 other value for each value at each level,
for each value you want to prove.
So there are thousands of values per that get touch per block.
That's a thousand times 15 values per level.
And if I remember correctly, the depth, the average depth of the MPT is between 10 and 15.
I don't remember exactly.
So that's a lot of data.
That's roughly, if you want to pass that data in a block, that's 3 megabytes.
We are in Bitcoin territory.
So, yeah, it's a bit too big to pass around the network in a reasonable time.
If you use the vertical commitment, so you have the equivalent, like you still have the -- oops,
that doesn't -- yes, you have the little cryptographic proof, but all you have to pass as your proof is the nodes
along the way to your value.
And that is much smaller, first of all, because you don't pass the siblings,
but on top of that, because you don't pass the siblings, there's a virtual cycle
that allows you to widen the tree.
You can have more children per tree per node.
And as a result, the tree gets shallower.
So your path is even smaller, even shorter.
And as a result, your proof is that much smaller.
So unfortunately, it's not that simple.
There's quite a few changes to introduce at the same time.
Like the first one is putting the proofs in the block.
That's the whole point.
But we also need to change the tree structure.
And I'm not going to get too deep into the details, because once again, it's quite involved.
There's an EIP.
There are other talks about it.
Look at them.
Look them up if you're interested.
But the idea is that all the data ends up in a single tree.
So currently, accounts have their own tree.
And for each account, you have another tree that encodes the storage for this account.
Well, here, everything is kind of, yeah, hashed or mixed together and spread over the tree.
Each item, like each account item, for example, the balance, the nonce, the code, any slot.
Like, for example, if you're thinking of crypto-kitty, each cat is accessed independently.
Because we don't want to add more to the proof that is required.
So if I'm sending funds to a new address, well, I just need the target address balance.
I don't need to know how much code they have.
I'm only interested in the funds.
And like I was saying, the data is spread all over the tree.
But we are trying to group things that belong together a little bit so that you don't spend
your time jumping all over the tree all the time.
So it's grouped in batches of 256.
And I'm going to go over that in just a bit.
So this is a picture that comes from the EIP itself.
I'm going to describe.
On the left side, you've got what's called the stem tree.
And it's basically the top of the tree.
So the tree is flipped to the side.
It's rotated 90 degrees to the left.
And the root, sorry, the stem tree only has a branch node.
So that means every node in that tree has at least two children.
When you take your key and you follow the pass traced by the key, at some point you will
reach a moment where there's only one group that is a group of 256 that is pointed out
by this key.
So there's this intermediate, like what's called an extension.
Yeah, I don't quite see the pointer here.
Sorry.
But the blue box, that extension says this is the prefix, the 31 byte prefix that every
key below me have like our keyed by.
So that means that if when you go through the tree and you have to compare the key that
you're using with the encoding, the key encoded in that blue box, and if it's the same, that
means your data is in the group below it, otherwise your data is not present in the
tree.
And there's the suffix tree so that corresponds to the 256 values.
And there's a force column that we're not going to cover.
It's not really important for this talk.
So like I said, every piece of data is broken into chunk.
That means for example the code is broken into bits into 31 byte pieces that are fitted
in a 32 byte piece.
The storage slots are also have their own data, the balance as its own value.
And each of these values, each of these chunks is given an offset.
And for example, the balance is always an offset one, the non-set offset two.
And then a bit further you have the beginning of where the code is supposed to start.
And then even further you have the bits where all the data slots are supposed to be.
And the way you find them in the tree is you take the address of, so you have a key that
is made of two parts.
The 31st bytes are called the stem and the suffix is just the byte that indexes in the
group that we saw before.
I'm talking about the third column here.
So the last byte is the index in there.
And so to build the stem what you do is you take the address of the account and you take
the first 31 bytes of the offset of that chunk.
And you hash them using what's called a peterson hash.
So it's like ketchup but it's much more friendly for ZK applications.
And it's also much slower but you get a 32 byte values, you take the 31st bytes of this
value and that gives you the stem.
And the way you use it when you compare it to the tree, the stem will give you the pass
through the stem tree and the extension.
And when you found that you use the suffix to select the value in the group.
So like I said, just a recap, vertical trees are nice because you can make the tree much
larger, much smaller, much more shallow, sorry.
You can also experiment with ideas like you could think.
So I know this is very interesting to dev developers.
You can just download the blockchain, not care about the state.
And when you look at the proof in the block at the witness, you can figure out if that
block is accessing something you're interested in.
So for example, if your crypto kitty, you want to see if the crypto kitty contract is
accessed.
If so, you just execute that block to update your internal state.
If not, you don't care.
Yeah.
And I was just a recap for the rest of the slide.
So what is the current state of vertical tree implementations?
We have one and a half running test nets.
We have one test net that is fully working.
It's a proof of work test net called Conbrijo.
I'll give the address at the end.
And so proof in blocks, it works.
It's been working for a while.
And then there's proof of stake test net that is currently in bring up phase.
So unfortunately, I wasn't able to get it to work for devcon, but it's going to happen
shortly.
When we do performance, we currently have performance testing.
We see that is currently five times slower than regular mainnet.
So when we replay blocks from mainnet on a translated vertical tree layer, it's five
times slower.
We took it down, it used to be 40x, so it's a bit faster already.
We have another avenue to make it faster.
But in my opinion, it's always going to be a bit slower than the current method, but
it offers some opportunities to build interesting applications.
So I think it's worth it.
And there are three implementations.
And there's a fourth one ongoing with base two.
So I don't know if it's quite readable, but I wanted to give an example of what you can
do with vertical trees.
So there's a block explorer on that test net, on the running test net.
And there's a piece of software that is able to read the block and reconstruct a view
of the network, sorry, of the tree, that is everything you know to re-execute the block
on top of it.
So I don't know if it's quite visible.
I still don't see the pointer.
But basically you can see that the leftmost branch here is an account.
The next branch, the right of it is another account.
I mean, I can tell because of the way the last level looks like.
And you have the other two branches from the root.
These do not have a very deep tree.
And that's because this is a proof of absence.
So that means this is the way you signal that those branches, those locations did not exist
before the execution of the block.
And what definitely happened here is that those two accounts on the left probably sent
funds to those two accounts on the right that did not exist yet.
And they will exist after the execution of the block.
So it's quite interesting because you can see what's going on.
You can visualize it this way without loading the whole tree.
Right.
So this is the current state.
What are the challenges we still have to overcome?
One of them is the transition.
Converting a miracle tree to a miracle tree is no walk in the park.
It requires a lot of ram.
It requires a lot of disk space.
And yeah, it's quite difficult.
So there are two methods, really two avenues to do this translation.
Either you entrust the conversion to very powerful machines.
I have a test machine that is a Xeon.
It takes it six days.
I know Arigun is able to do it in less than a day, but even for Arigun it's not instant.
And where was I?
Yes.
So that's the first avenue.
The second avenue we have to do the translation is simply to pace it to the slowest machine
on the network.
So that would be to do a translation of, let's say, five, ten, a hundred values per
block.
But this would last for a month.
But then every node on the network would theoretically be able to follow.
So these methods have names.
The one where, like you follow the pace of the network, it's called the overlay tree.
The other one was called offline conversion.
There's a third one that is known as the roll-up appreciation week where you just do nothing
for a week or a month and you wait for everybody to be done translating.
That's just here because it's a cool name.
No one's really considering that.
Yeah, one last thing I wanted to say about this slide is pre-images.
So most clients, including Geth, do not encode the addresses directly.
They just write the hash of those addresses.
So to do the translation and because we use a different hash system, we need the pre-images.
It turns out that most clients do not store that.
Erigan does, but the rest of them don't.
So pre-image availability is another problem that needs to be addressed and it's not an
easy one.
Another thing is the slower cryptographic primitives.
It's not as fast as Ketchak.
So this is one of the latest runs.
And you can see that roughly 3%, 35% is spent just doing elliptic curve operations.
So cryptographic primitives is really where the effort needs to be, the optimization effort
needs to be made.
So either by writing faster crypto or by not calling those functions as much.
So Ketching, for example, is a technique that has worked well.
Yeah, there's a slide on database design.
So basically the idea is that current most clients have written their optimized their
database layout and their database access layer for the current MPT.
A lot of those assumptions are no longer valid, let alone helpful with vertical trees.
So there will be some need to adapt to something that is a bit close to what Erigan is doing,
but that will take time, unfortunately.
And I wanted to finish on what you can do if you want to help.
The first thing would be there are test nets.
So the first thing you can do is just try to deploy your contracts on the test net and
see if that works.
If you can also try to run your own client, like #testingtheverge, you can also modify
a CL client to figure out how to propagate the proofs because currently it hasn't been
defined.
So it would be interesting to run a fact finding machine, finding out where and how the proofs
need to be propagated in a proof of stake world.
Like I said, crypto is the bottleneck.
So if you can find a better cryptographic primitive than what we have, that would be also quite
helpful.
It's also going to affect layer two solutions, like presumably layer two groups don't really
want to diverge too much from the main net.
They will need to adapt as well.
There's not a clear pass for that yet.
Like I said, preimages are also a problem.
If you have a way to make preimages available to everyone, that's a very good test, very
useful.
And then you can go crazy.
You can try to prototype the interaction of vertical tree with the portal network, with
try to implement state expiry using vertical trees, all of that.
None of that is greenfield, but it's also quite interesting to get some information, some
ideas of what is to come.
And with this, that's pretty much it.
I have put addresses of the two test nets, knowing that the second one is still in a
bring-up phase, so it will probably not work today.
But the other one is the landing page for the proof-of-work test net, and this one works,
or should work.
And you can look at the explorer, you can send transaction, you can try everything.
And that's it.
[MUSIC]
>> Thank you so much, Guillaume.
Guillaume, do you mind taking a minute to answer questions?
>> I'm going to throw it at you.
>> If you do have any questions for Guillaume, go ahead and raise your hand, and one of
the volunteers will actually come towards you.
There's a question right there in the fourth row, fifth row with a black sweatshirt.
>> You mentioned accessing data is going to be a little bit different.
Does this imply that, like, tooling teams and wallets and such, and I are going to have
to enforce access lists now moving forward?
>> No, it doesn't mean that, but it means that the gas model is going to change to follow
this new model, which is why I was like, if you've got a contract, please deploy it on
the test net.
But you do not need access lists are going to disappear.
They're replaced by something else that is not really exposed to the user.
So for the end user, in theory, apart from the gas cost, everything will be transparent.
>> Oh, there's one more question.
Do you mind answering one more?
Can I repeat the question real quick?
>> Oh, sure.
>> I'm just going to paraphrase it real quick.
They said that they wanted to know if there's any drawbacks to the vertical trees.
>> Yes, there's plenty of drawbacks.
Like I said, there's the transition, the slow crypto.
Otherwise, yes, like the biggest drawback I only alluded to in the previous answer, it's
that the gas model changes.
And that means that a lot of code, you know, like contracts tend to, some contracts tend
to be very optimized for gas.
Those optimization can turn out to be completely obsolete and counterproductive.
So I would say that's the biggest drawback I can think of.
>> Awesome.
If you have any other questions for Guillaume, I'm sure you'll be over to the side.
Feel free to ask them after the talk, too.
>> Thank you.
>> Awesome, thank you.
[ Applause ]
[ Silence ]
[ Silence ]
